The cramps would not dissipate, but neither would Westbrook's determination to keep playing.  As the Giants' Tiki Barber was preparing to retire, Westbrook came into playoff prominence for Philadelphia. He skittered 49 yards for a second-quarter touchdown, then rushed for four first downs on the Eagles' final drive to set up the winning 38-yard field goal in a 23-20 victory.  ''I wasn't feeling very good,'' Westbrook said of his intestinal discomfort after rushing 20 times for 141 yards. But, he added, ''I wouldn't miss being out there.''  Much of his success came on what Philadelphia calls an outside zone play. Right tackle Jon Runyan seals off the inside, and fullback Thomas Tapeh occupies the outside linebacker, leaving Westbrook one on one with a safety or another linebacker. On the final drive in particular, Runyan said, the Giants kept blitzing and Westbrook ran right through the blitz.  ''You have to get positive yards on first down,'' Runyan said. ''It makes it easy for you. The defense doesn't know what you are doing. I don't think we had a third down on that drive until the field goal.''  It was hard to imagine it after Westbrook ran through and around the Giants, but there have long been questions here about him. Not about his ability to run or catch the ball, but about his ability to stay healthy.  Philadelphia threw the football at a rate unmatched in N.F.L. history -- 58.4 percent of the time -- in Coach Andy Reid's eighth season in Philadelphia. The main reason was the lively arm of quarterback Donovan McNabb. But, many suspect, Reid also did not trust that Westbrook could stay healthy enough to carry a punishing load at running back.  In any case, desperation forced Reid's hand.  When McNabb tore a ligament in his knee in November, the Eagles tore up their game plan. Lost was their big-play passing attack. To protect the replacement quarterback, Jeff Garcia, the Eagles grew somewhat cautious. Balance replaced ostentation.  Philadelphia began running as much as it passed in winning five consecutive games to end the regular season and to win the National Football Conference East. And the Eagles kept running during Sunday's wild-card playoff victory against the Giants.  ''He was very patient, and let things develop in front of him, and hit it,'' Reid said of Westbrook. ''It's not speed to the hole; it's speed through the hole. He's developed a good feel for that through the years.''  Before the game, Giants cornerback R. W. McQuarters compared Westbrook to a young Marshall Faulk, meaning that Westbrook was threatening and resourceful at both running and catching the ball. It was no hyperbole. Westbrook led all N.F.L. running backs this season by averaging 6 yards a touch.  ''Brian Westbrook is one of the few elite players in this league,'' said Marty Mornhinweg, the Eagles' offensive coordinator.  On Sunday, Westbrook also returned punts, and sliced through a porous Giants coverage team for a 65-yard return to the end zone that was nullified by a penalty for an illegal block in the back.  But Westbrook's most impressive achievement this season has been running the ball. He gained a career-high 1,217 yards in the regular season and became the first Eagle to rush for at least 1,000 yards while averaging 5 yards a carry.  Until now, there has been frequent and legitimate concern about his durability at 5 feet 8 inches, 203 pounds. He missed the playoffs after the 2003 season with a torn triceps tendon in his left arm. A year ago, his season ended prematurely because of a sprained foot. Earlier this season, Westbrook was bothered by a balky knee, and rumors spread here -- inaccurately -- that he might need surgery.  But he has been resilient and reliable since McNabb became injured, averaging about seven more carries a game.  ''It's a percentage thing,'' Runyan said of Westbrook. ''You give it to him, and he's going to do something with it. He's staying healthy and we're seeing what the guy can do.''  After the Eagles struggled early on Sunday, Westbrook sprinted around the right side from the Giants' 49-yard line early in the second quarter. Defensive end Adrian Awasom dived at Westbrook's feet, but could not bring him down. Safety Will Demps's effort was also futile, as Westbrook stutter-stepped one way, then went the other, jogging into the end zone to tie the score at 7-7.  Then, on the final drive, he exhausted the clock, and the Giants' chances.  ''It was a critical situation, and big-time players step up when you need them the most,'' Westbrook said.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: In Despair, Eagles Turn to Westbrook to Help Carry Them

content.text: To reach the Super Bowl, to finally fill in the blanks on the glittering résumés that lacked postseason glory, even the Indianapolis Colts conceded it was only appropriate that they would have to vanquish their greatest tormentors.  The New England Patriots had used the Colts as doormats on two of their three Super Bowl runs, stepping over them on the way to constructing a dynasty. But Sunday night, like the kids who had had enough of being beaten up by the class bullies, the Colts fought back. They rallied from an 18-point deficit, then traded scores with the Patriots in a thrilling second half to win the American Football Conference title, 38-34, and advance to Super Bowl XLI on Feb. 4 in Miami.  There, the Colts will play the Chicago Bears, who won the National Football Conference championship game earlier in the day, creating a meeting of great significance: Colts Coach Tony Dungy and Bears Coach Lovie Smith, Dungy's close friend, will become the first black head coaches to lead teams at the Super Bowl.  The victory also sent quarterback Peyton Manning to the Super Bowl for the first time, and he and Dungy can leave behind some of their baggage -- that their successful careers may never be capped by their sport's greatest honor. This was an especially meaningful performance by Manning (27 of 47 for 349 yards and a touchdown), who was criticized for his previous postseason failures as much as he was praised for his statistical dominance.  But he recovered from a shaky start to produce scoring drive after scoring drive in a relentless second half that included a total of eight scores, four of them Colts touchdowns.  The comeback was the biggest in championship game history, and the brilliance of Manning's regular-season play finally transferred to the postseason with a winning drive that may rival the one produced by John Elway against Cleveland 20 years ago. The seven-play, 80-yard drive, which included a pinpoint-perfect 32-yard pass to tight end Bryan Fletcher on the left sideline, ended with the winning touchdown -- a 3-yard run by Joseph Addai with one minute left. It was the first time the Colts led in the game.  Celebration of Dungy's historical milestone, he said, could wait for another day. He wanted the Colts, who had struggled with a leaky run defense all season and had lost three of their last five regular-season games, to enjoy their first trip to the Super Bowl since the Colts moved to Indianapolis in 1984.  ''We had to do it the hard way,'' Dungy said. ''We had to go through a great champion. It's fitting. Our team went the hard way the whole year.''  The Colts endured a remarkable early onslaught by the Patriots, who took a 21-3 lead in the second quarter when Patriots cornerback Asante Samuel returned an interception 39 yards for a touchdown. Manning said later that he had wanted to make up for that play, and he would get his chance much later. But the beginning of the comeback was nearly unnoticed by Colts fans, who were stunned into silence by the yawning deficit.  The Colts kicked a field goal just before the end of the first half, cutting their deficit to 21-6, and that, Dungy said, infused the locker room with energy during halftime. He spoke to his players about being just two scores down, and said that if they could get a good kickoff return and score on their opening drive, they would trail by just one score. Dungy's calm permeates the Colts, and when Manning scored on a 1-yard sneak on the first Colts drive of the third quarter, a blowout was on its way to becoming an instant classic.  ''You don't envision getting down, 21-3, to the New England Patriots,'' Manning said. ''It didn't feel like things were going that bad. It was my fault it was 21-3.''  It was the defense's fault that the Colts had played so poorly at the end of the regular season, losing their bid to have home-field advantage throughout the playoffs. But the defense, with the fireplug safety Bob Sanders back from a knee injury, righted itself when the playoffs began, carrying the team to victories against the Chiefs and the Ravens even as Manning struggled. The Colts relied on the defense again to start the comeback.  When they held the Patriots to three downs and out on their first drive of the third quarter, Dungy's halftime speech proved prophetic in the most improbable way. The Colts are laden with offensive talent, but Manning's first touchdown pass of the game did not go to one of his high-profile receivers. It went instead to Dan Klecko, a backup defensive tackle who used to play for New England. Manning rolled to his right and hit Klecko for the 1-yard touchdown pass.  When Marvin Harrison, who was held to four receptions for 41 yards by the Patriots, spun around to catch a 2-point conversion, the score was suddenly -- and very briefly -- tied.  Patriots cornerback Ellis Hobbs had set up that touchdown when he bumped receiver Reggie Wayne in the end zone, giving the Colts first-and-goal on the 1. Redemption came quickly. Hobbs returned the ensuing kickoff 80 yards to put the Patriots at the Colts' 21.  On third-and-goal from the 6, Patriots quarterback Tom Brady saw Jabar Gaffney in the back of the end zone. Gaffney leaped and caught the pass, coming down with his left foot inbounds. Officials ruled that he was pushed out, so the touchdown counted. But a replay on the RCA Dome's video screen indicated that Gaffney might have stepped out of bounds before he leaped for the ball. The touchdown stood and the Patriots led again.  The scoring continued until the Colts finally halted the Patriots at the Colts' 25. The Patriots rookie kicker Stephen Gostkowski kicked a 43-yard field goal to give the Patriots a 34-31 lead with 3:49 remaining.  ''We let too many opportunities get away,'' Brady said. ''We had the ball in good field position at certain times. We should have got the ball in the end zone.''  In years past, a 3-point lead would have been enough for the Patriots to cling to. But they have been unusually erratic this season, and of all things, their defense failed them this time. They looked exhausted, and that was just enough of an opening for Manning, whose record-setting career had lacked a defining moment.  By hitting Fletcher on a play that Fletcher called for himself, the triumphs that had so often belonged to Brady and the Patriots in the past six years were finally snatched away by Manning. When Addai ran in untouched to put Indianapolis ahead, Manning worried that the Colts had left too much time on the clock. He got to the bench and bowed his head, praying, as the Patriots took over with only a minute left.  When cornerback Marlin Jackson intercepted Brady's pass at the Colts' 35 with 16 seconds to play, the Patriots' stranglehold on the Colts was over, and so was Manning's postseason futility. The dynasty was put aside while the monkey was removed from Manning's back.  ''I don't know if you're supposed to pray for things like that,'' Manning said. ''I can remember the disappointment of three years ago, when we lost the A.F.C. championship in Foxborough. I don't get into monkeys or vindication. I don't play that card.''  But Manning had gotten those 7 points back. And he had, at long last, led the Colts to the Super Bowl. Prayers answered.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: OFF TO MIAMI, NO BAGGAGE

content.text: There was doubt last week whether Giants tight end Jeremy Shockey would play, but he started in Sunday's 23-20 first-round playoff loss against the Philadelphia Eagles.  Early in the game, it was not clear how effective Shockey would be. He caught an 8-yard pass in the first quarter but he frequently limped after plays because of a left ankle injury he sustained two weeks ago.  In the second quarter, he looked more like the Shockey of old.  With the Giants trailing by 10-7, quarterback Eli Manning completed a short pass to Shockey on first down. Shockey's helmet flew off as he was hit by an Eagles defender, but he remained on his feet and stretched the play into an 11-yard reception that gave the Giants a first down at their 42.  With his helmet still off, he distanced himself from the players near him and then spun the ball on the Lincoln Financial Field grass. Shockey the showboat was officially back.  Two plays after that reception, the Giants faced a third-and-2 at midfield. Manning again looked to Shockey, who kept the drive alive by reaching for a pass and gaining 6 yards and a first down at the Eagles' 44.  On the next play, Tiki Barber rode the momentum that Shockey had generated, running for 41 yards.  Shockey was unable to corral a lob from Manning near the left corner of the end zone three plays later, and the Giants settled for Jay Feely's 20-yard field goal to tie the score, 10-10.  Shockey finished the first half with a team-high three receptions for 25 yards. Unfortunately for the Giants, Shockey did not add to those numbers in the second half. He had a total of three catches in last year's 23-0 playoff loss to the Carolina Panthers.  Shockey played in every game in the regular season except the finale, a 34-28 road victory against the Washington Redskins that sealed a playoff berth for the Giants. Shockey was injured six days earlier going for a pass from Manning in a 30-7 loss at home to the New Orleans Saints. His swollen and sore left ankle kept him out of practice until last Wednesday.  Shockey said last week that he would do everything in his power to play against the Eagles and help erase the memories of last season's loss to the Panthers. But the few first-half plays he made Sunday were not enough to accomplish that.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: For Shockey, A Fast Start Winds Down With a Fizzle

content.text: The Chicago Bears won one more game than the Indianapolis Colts in the 2006 regular season. The Bears outscored their opponents by 172 points, and the Colts outscored theirs by 67. The Bears won the National Football Conference championship in a blowout, while the Colts needed a late comeback to beat New England in the American Football Conference title game.  Yet most football fans believe the Colts will win the Super Bowl, thanks to the A.F.C.'s well-deserved reputation as the N.F.L.'s superior conference.  This season, A.F.C. teams went 40-24 during interconference play. The Bears (13-3) were no exception; until the final week of the season, their only losses had come against A.F.C. opponents. The four N.F.C. division champions went a combined 6-10 against the A.F.C., and Dallas was the only N.F.C. team with a winning interconference record.  This imbalance of power is not limited to 2006. Except for 2000, when the series was tied at 30-30, the A.F.C. has had a winning record against the N.F.C. every season since 1996. A.F.C. teams have also won seven of the past nine Super Bowls, beginning with Denver's upset of Green Bay in Super Bowl XXXII.  Most observers believe the dominance of one conference over the other is cyclical. After Green Bay won the first two Super Bowls, the American Football League/A.F.C. won 11 of the next 13. During the '80s, the balance of power shifted, and the N.F.C. won 13 straight Super Bowls, from 1985 through 1997.  Look past the Super Bowl, however, and the shift of power from one conference to the other is not quite so cyclical. When the N.F.C. was winning those 13 straight titles, its dominance was generally limited to a few successful franchises, not the conference as a whole. The N.F.C. had the better interconference record in only 6 of those 13 seasons.  Buffalo's streak of four Super Bowl losses from 1991 through 1994 is often brought up as evidence of the N.F.C.'s superiority at that time. The Bills won most of their A.F.C. playoff games by large margins, only to lose to the N.F.C.'s best season after season.  But 1991 and 1992 were the only two seasons since 1972 when the N.F.C. won at least 55 percent of the interconference games. By comparison, the A.F.C. has won more than 60 percent of interconference games twice in the past three seasons.  The highest point of A.F.C. dominance came between 1974 and 1980. The A.F.C. won at least 57 percent of the interconference games those seasons, peaking in 1979 when the A.F.C. was 36-16 against football's senior circuit.  An 8-8 team stumbling into the N.F.C. playoffs, like this season's Giants, is nothing new. Nine teams have made the playoffs despite only eight wins in a 16-game season, and seven were N.F.C. squads.  It is one thing to show that the A.F.C. has been the better conference, of course, and another to explain why. Common theories about the A.F.C.'s current superiority may not apply to its overall dominance since 1972.  Many experts believe today's A.F.C. simply has better talent, especially at one position. ''I think you can tie the success or failure to who has the best quarterbacks,'' said Gil Brandt, the longtime Dallas personnel director who now works as an analyst for the NFL Network.  ''That doesn't always hold true, but this year, Tom Brady is not going to the Pro Bowl, while for the N.F.C., Tony Romo is going to the Pro Bowl,'' Brandt said. ''Not taking anything away from Tony Romo, but which one would you rather have as your quarterback?''  The quarterback theory is commonly tied to the N.F.C.'s 13-year Super Bowl streak, when Troy Aikman, Joe Montana and Steve Young were all championship quarterbacks. It would also explain why the Super Bowl streak was not matched by similar N.F.C. dominance in interconference play. If one conference has most of the star quarterbacks, it does not necessarily mean that it has the best quarterbacks from top to bottom.  But the quarterback theory does not quite stand up. Many of those A.F.C. championship teams were also led by great quarterbacks: Dan Marino, John Elway and Jim Kelly. Hall of Fame quarterbacks started for 8 of the 13 champions during that N.F.C. streak -- but also for 8 of the 13 A.F.C. teams that lost to them.  Another explanation for the A.F.C.'s recent dominance may be coaching continuity. Five A.F.C. coaches in 2006 had been with their teams for more than five seasons, including three who were with the same team for 12 seasons or more: Mike Shanahan of Denver, Jeff Fisher of Tennessee and Bill Cowher of Pittsburgh (who resigned after the end of this season). Contrast that with the N.F.C., where only two coaches were with the same team for more than five seasons: Andy Reid of Philadelphia and Mike Holmgren of Seattle, eight seasons each.  On average, the 16 A.F.C. coaches last season were with their teams two years longer than their N.F.C. counterparts.  The N.F.C. did not have a similar advantage during its Super Bowl streak, however. From 1984 to 1996, the average A.F.C. coach had roughly one season more experience than those in the N.F.C. When the A.F.C. was dominant in the '70s, the N.F.C. coaches actually had a slight lead in average experience.  No matter which N.F.C. team won last week, the A.F.C. was bound to be the favorite in Super Bowl XLI. And even if the Bears win next Sunday, the N.F.C. will probably be the inferior conference next season -- as it will be in the season after that, and as it has been for most of the past 35 years.  KEEPING SCORE E-mail: keepingscore@nytimes.com
content.title: Between A.F.C. and N.F.C., Parity Is Only a Six-Letter Word

content.text: A report in the Fifth Down football roundup on Thursday about the American Football Conference's dominance over the National Football Conference during the regular season misstated the N.F.C. playoff team that had the best record (3-1) against A.F.C. teams. It is the Dallas Cowboys -- not the Giants, who were 1-3.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: The Indianapolis Colts, the team of Peyton Manning and the franchise that once had the legendary quarterback Johnny Unitas, probably never thought they would rely on a formula like this to win in the playoffs: Let the defense stop the opponent, have the place-kicker score all the points, and hope the offense does not make too many mistakes.  Who did they think they were -- the Baltimore Ravens? The Ravens, the team that brought football back to Baltimore, patented that game plan when they won the Super Bowl in 2001. But the Colts borrowed a page from that playbook Saturday, beating the Ravens, 15-6, to advance to next Sunday's American Football Conference championship game.  The Colts, for years the N.F.L.'s most dazzling offense, won in the most unexpected fashion -- without scoring a touchdown and by allowing fewer than 10 points for the second time in the playoffs. They have made their way through the playoffs without the white-hot spotlight and the staggering weight of outside expectations bearing down on them. Manning, whose postseason struggles have threatened to blemish his career résumé, has thrown five interceptions and only one touchdown pass in the past two games.  But if the New England Patriots defeat the San Diego Chargers in Sunday's A.F.C. playoff game, the Colts will play host to the championship game -- a perk they were supposed to enjoy last year, when they were the overwhelming favorite to reach the Super Bowl.  In the waning moments of the victory, after Adam Vinatieri had nailed his fifth field goal, Colts Coach Tony Dungy stood beside defensive tackle Anthony McFarland. Dungy and McFarland had been together in Tampa Bay, too, when the Buccaneers' repeated playoff runs were foiled by a terrible offense. The Bucs fired Dungy for his failure to win a title and he was quickly hired by the Colts, who hoped he would build a defense that would be a complement to Manning's offense.  With two smothering defensive efforts in the playoffs so far, Dungy seems to be fulfilling his mandate at precisely the moment when Manning has stumbled. So, on the sideline, Dungy and McFarland christened the Colts' victory: Call it Buc-ball.  ''We won a lot of games like this,'' Dungy said of his Buccaneers. ''We were having a laugh. These guys are all nervous. Every game we won, we won like this. It's Ravens ball. We outplayed them at their game.''  Actually, the Ravens have never had a quarterback like Manning. But the arrival of quarterback Steve McNair, who once shared league most valuable player honors with Manning, energized the offense and created a balance with the defense that propelled the Ravens to the No. 2 seeding in the A.F.C.  But on Saturday both offenses were virtually beside the point. This was just the fourth time in N.F.L. history, and the first since 1979, that neither team scored a touchdown in a playoff game. The Ravens had the best defense in the league this season, but Manning said he could not recall, in his nine seasons in the N.F.L., ever winning a game without scoring at least one touchdown.  Except for the outcome, this was a forgettable performance for him. Scrambling to avoid pressure, Manning frequently overthrew his receivers. He was intercepted twice while completing only 15 of 30 pass attempts, statistically an even worse day than McNair had, with his two interceptions and 18-of-29 passing. Manning's 39.6 quarterback rating was nearly as bad as the 35.5 rating he posted when the Patriots battered the Colts in the 2005 A.F.C. championship game.  ''The plan coming in was to score touchdowns,'' Manning said, laughing. ''We were not planning to score 35 points, but we thought maybe 20 points. I knew it would be tough sledding.''  But Manning completed the most important pass of the game, in the middle of a clock-chewing fourth-quarter drive that kept the ball out of the Ravens' hands when they were trailing by only 6 points. On third-and-5 from Baltimore's 45, Manning zipped a pass to tight end Dallas Clark, who was blanketed by Ravens cornerback Corey Ivy.  At the most critical moment, the Ravens' defense could not make a stop. The Colts' defense, particularly against the run, was shredded for most of the regular season, but with the return of safety Bob Sanders from an injury that forced him to miss almost all of the regular season, the Colts have had consecutive lockdown performances. They held the Chiefs' Larry Johnson to 32 yards rushing last week, then held the Ravens to 83. They thwarted Baltimore's preferred style to get an early lead and then unleashed blitzes.  The Ravens never had the lead because the Colts had the one weapon they lacked last season: a reliable field-goal kicker. The Colts signed Vinatieri away from the Patriots expressly for games like this.  Last season ended for the Colts when Mike Vanderjagt badly missed a field goal in the divisional round. The league's most dynamic offense, and the improving defense, could do nothing to replace those 3 points, so the Colts replaced Vanderjagt as soon as free agency started with Vinatieri, one of the most clutch kickers in N.F.L. history.  Vinatieri has had plenty of highlight-reel moments, none more memorable than his successful field goals in a blizzard against the Oakland Raiders that propelled the Patriots to their first Super Bowl title. But if the Colts go to the Super Bowl, Vinatieri might have provided an omen to their postseason.  His third field goal of the game, late in the second quarter, was a 51-yarder. He did not hit it well and the ball seemed to die as it got near the goal post. It barely hit the cross bar and with its last bit of momentum, it bounced over.  It was not pretty, but it got through. Just like the Colts.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Colts Push Onward in Playoffs, Advancing 3 Points at a Time

content.text: Tom Brady has won many games by erasing fourth-quarter deficits, leading last-minute drives, throwing improbable touchdown passes.  On Sunday, Brady proved that he can truly do it all -- he won a game by throwing an interception.  The New England Patriots are moving to the American Football Conference championship game against the Colts, largely because their starting quarterback made one terrible mistake. With the Patriots trailing by 8 points, late in the fourth quarter and facing a fourth down, Brady threw an untimely interception.  It looked like the end of the Patriots' season. It was actually the beginning of their rally. New England defeated the San Diego Chargers at Qualcomm Stadium, 24-21, thanks to the immaculate interception.  Once the ball left Brady's hand, he knew it was off-target. It was so off-target, in fact, that it went right to safety Marlon McCree. If the pass had been a little better, it would have fallen incomplete, and the Chargers would have taken control.  Instead, McCree caught the ball and started running. He charged into the middle of the field, toward a herd of New England players. He carried the ball a few inches from his body, providing a narrow window of opportunity for the Patriots.  ''I was trying to make a play,'' McCree said. ''Anytime I get the ball, I am going to try to score.''  Troy Brown, a New England receiver who moonlights as a cornerback, immediately turned into a defender. He attacked McCree and swiped at the ball, stripping it loose. Watching the sequence unfold, and seeing the Patriots recover the ball, Brady could not believe his good fortune. The football fates were smiling on him again.  With one more chance, Brady drove for a tying touchdown and 2-point conversion, and a winning field goal. Stephen Gostkowski, the New England place-kicker, made a 31-yard field goal with 1 minute 10 seconds left. Nate Kaeding, the San Diego place-kicker, missed a 54-yard attempt to tie the score with 8 seconds left.  Afterward, Brady took a deep breath. ''That was not easy,'' he said.  Brady has won three Super Bowls and his playoff record is 12-1, but the degree of difficulty keeps increasing. The Patriots lose assistants (Eric Mangini, Charlie Weis and Romeo Crennel) and they lose receivers (Deion Branch and David Givens). But sometimes, especially in January, Brady is all they seem to need.  As Brady rejoiced with his teammates after the game, LaDainian Tomlinson rushed off the field, refusing to shake hands with the New England players. Tomlinson, the San Diego running back and the Most Valuable Player of the N.F.L., was enraged that the Patriots were dancing and gloating at midfield.  The Patriots cannot seem to celebrate a playoff victory this season without some kind of incident. Last week, Coach Bill Belichick shoved a photographer after a victory against the Jets. This week, Tomlinson accused the Patriots of a lack of class.  ''I can't sit there and watch that,'' Tomlinson said. ''I was very upset. They showed no class at all, absolutely no class, and maybe it comes from their head coach.''  Tomlinson had reason to be frustrated. He finished with 187 all-purpose yards and scored 2 touchdowns, but he got little help. Suffering from butter-fingers and brain freeze, the Chargers dropped six passes, committed four turnovers and wasted a couple of timeouts.  Brady was hardly flawless either. He threw three interceptions and labored through three and a half quarters, but he delivered one vintage pass. Facing a third-and-10 at his 34-yard line, with less than three minutes remaining and the crowd howling, Brady told receiver Reche Caldwell to run a go route.  Caldwell, let go by the Chargers after last season, was single covered by cornerback Quentin Jammer. With one move at the line of scrimmage, Caldwell froze Jammer and bolted past him. They both sprinted up the San Diego sideline.  Forty-nine yards later, Caldwell held the ball and New England held the game. ''I had a chance to come home and show what I can do,'' Caldwell said. ''This means a lot. It's a lot of gratification.''  But the catch was not his most significant contribution. When Brown stripped McCree of his interception, Caldwell was the one who pounced on the fumble and held it at the bottom of the pile. ''That was the big play of the game,'' Caldwell said.  New England now gets to play at Indianapolis on Sunday, a daunting task for many teams, but not necessarily for the Patriots. New England has traditionally rattled the Colts and Brady has consistently upstaged Indianapolis quarterback Peyton Manning.  The Chargers, meanwhile, could soon be embarking on a coaching search. Even though they posted a 14-2 record in the regular season and won 10 games in a row, Coach Marty Schottenheimer failed again in the playoffs.  Schottenheimer could be doomed by his 5-13 playoff record -- with Cleveland, Kansas City and San Diego -- and his strained relationship with the Chargers' general manager, A. J. Smith. Smith and Schottenheimer rarely speak, and Smith has not given Schottenheimer a public endorsement for next season.  ''Not withstanding the disappointment and frustration of the events of this day, I'll choose to look at this team in a very positive light,'' Schottenheimer said.  He may be judged on a decision he made in the first quarter Sunday, when he decided to go for a fourth-and-11 at the New England 30, instead of using his Pro Bowl kicker, Kaeding, for a field goal.  Schottenheimer apparently wanted to show that he had changed his conservative ways, but the fourth-down play failed and it set the tone for the rest of game.  ''They might have gotten a little tight,'' Patriots linebacker Mike Vrabel said.  Schottenheimer has lost playoff games in some of the most creative and excruciating ways imaginable. Some of his playoff losses are so memorable that they even have their own nicknames:  The Drive. The Fumble. And, now, The Interception.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: For the Bears and the Patriots, It's All Good

content.text: For the Jets and the Giants, today is a rare happy New Year: It is only the fifth time the two New York pro football franchises have been together in the Super Bowl tournament.  That's together in a Sunday doubleheader, but not in momentum, with the Jets soaring into New England for a 1 p.m. game and the Giants stumbling into Philadelphia at 4:30 p.m.  The Jets (10-6) won five of their past six games, including yesterday's 23-3 domination of the Raiders.  The Giants, with Tiki Barber slashing for 234 rushing yards and 3 touchdowns in Saturday night's 34-28 triumph against the Redskins, squeezed into the playoffs with an 8-8 record after losing six of their previous seven games.  To listen to quarterback Chad Pennington's synopsis of the Jets' success, it would seem that the teams are not together in another important area.  ''It's about the players believing in the coach, and the coaches believing in the players,'' Pennington said.  The way the Jets finished their relatively easy schedule, they surely believe in Coach Eric Mangini, who finally used the word playoffs in a sentence after his Gatorade shower, and he believes in them. But the way the Giants had to depend on Barber to outscore the Redskins, a 5-11 disappointment, it's difficult to know if they believe in Coach Tom Coughlin and his staff, and if Coughlin believes in his injury-depleted roster.  An 8-8 record is not necessarily a quick lose-and-out for a wild card. In the years since the 16-game schedule began in 1978, six other 8-8 teams reached the playoffs via the wild card and two of them won an opening-round game on the road before losing in the divisional round.  Two years ago, the Vikings and the Rams were 8-8 in gaining the National Football Conference playoffs. The Vikings upset the Packers, 31-17, before losing to the Eagles, 27-14; and the Rams stunned the Seahawks, 27-20, before losing to the Falcons, 47-17.  The four 8-8 wild-card teams that lost in the opening round included the 1991 Jets, who fell in Houston, 17-10, after sneaking into the playoffs with an overtime victory in Miami, as well as the 1999 Cowboys, the 1999 Lions and the 1990 Saints.  The 1985 Browns won their division with an 8-8 record and lost to the Dolphins in their first playoff game.  In a third coaching chess match between Mangini and his mentor, Bill Belichick, the Jets would seem to have a puncher's chance against the Patriots, whom they defeated, 17-14, in Foxborough after an early season 24-17 loss at Giants Stadium. But it won't be easy for Pennington to win a passing duel with Tom Brady, a three-time Super Bowl winner. The Giants don't seem to have the manpower (and maybe the will power) to upset the Eagles, especially in Philadelphia.  The Giants split with the Eagles, winning by 30-24 in overtime in Philadelphia on Eli Manning's three touchdown passes, but losing, 36-22, at Giants Stadium a little more than two weeks ago.  Against the Redskins on Saturday night, Barber had the best game any Giants running back ever had, especially when a victory meant so much not only to him as the last regular-season game of his career before he disappears into a television studio, but also to the salvation of a season that loomed as a disaster.  For all the wonderful games played by the Giants' Hall of Fame running backs -- Frank Gifford, Tuffy Leemans and Ken Strong -- and by Joe Morris and Rodney Hampton, none of those stars carried the Giants the way Barber did at FedEx Field, across the Potomac River from Virginia, where he grew up as a Redskins fan.  But against the Eagles in what could be his last game, Barber will be running against one of the N.F.L.'s toughest defenses. There won't be many holes for him to dart through, and the Eagles' demon safety, Brian Dawkins, won't be as easy to outrun as the Redskins.  The Jets not only survived, but thrived without their future Hall of Fame running back Curtis Martin, the fourth-leading career rusher in pro football with more 14,000 yards. Martin was never activated after having knee surgery late last season -- another tribute to Mangini's day-to-day mantra for his players: Try to win the next game and try to make progress.  ''We haven't had the time to doubt ourselves and to ask, what if?'' Pennington said, alluding to Martin. ''It's been full go since Day 1. Our young guys who haven't had opportunities before but had them now have stepped to the forefront. Each week, somebody you may not have heard from stepped up and made the play. That's what football is all about.''  In Martin's absence, the rookie Leon Washington, a fourth-round selection with the draft choice awarded to the Jets when the Chiefs hired Herman Edwards as their coach, rushed for 650 yards. Cedric Houston had 374 and Kevan Barlow 370.  That adds up to 1,394 yards, about what a healthy Martin might have had. But a yard is a yard is a yard, no matter who gets it. So the Jets, riding Pennington's cool comeback from his second rotator-cuff operation, are soaring into the playoffs as the Giants stumble in. And for only the fifth time, they're both there.  SPORTS OF THE TIMES
content.title: One Team Thrives on Chemistry; Another Survives Without It

content.text: Stephen Gostkowski said he cleared his mind as he searched for a kicking path between distant uprights, the road that might deliver the New England Patriots to the American Football Conference championship game.  Gostkowski said he did not burden himself with the pressure of the moment, the shoes he was trying to fill or the feat he was aiming to accomplish in his first season in the N.F.L.  ''I don't think about that stuff,'' Gostkowski said after nailing a 31-yard field goal with 1 minute 10 seconds remaining in an A.F.C. second-round playoff game, which lifted New England to a 24-21 victory against the San Diego Chargers on Sunday at Qualcomm Stadium. ''We kick 200 kicks a week. It seemed like any other kick to me.''  One day after Adam Vinatieri, the former Patriots place-kicker, connected on five field goals for the Indianapolis Colts and reminded the Patriots of what they had lost, Gostkowski helped the Patriots move on without him.  Gostkowski also made field goals of 50 and 34 yards, making him 6 for 6 in the postseason and adding a dependable weapon to a Patriots arsenal headlined by quarterback Tom Brady.  Gostkowski's clutch kicks stood out especially because of how the game ended, with San Diego's kicker, Nate Kaeding, failing to make a 54-yard attempt with eight seconds remaining that would have tied the score.  ''I knew I had to hit it on the screws,'' said Kaeding, who missed a field-goal attempt in overtime against the Jets in the playoffs after the 2004 season. ''I just didn't have enough juice on it.''  Gostkowski said of Kaeding: ''He's a good kicker, and he's got a Pro Bowl in him. He's just got to keep his head up.''  The Chargers had a chance to use Kaeding earlier, but San Diego Coach Marty Schottenheimer passed up a 48-yard field-goal attempt on fourth-and-11 in the first quarter. Instead, linebacker Mike Vrabel sacked Philip Rivers, causing a fumble that New England recovered.  ''I thought we had a play that we could use that would make the yardage,'' Schottenheimer said. ''The intention was to be very aggressive, and I thought we had a play that would get it.''  The Patriots turned the error into Gostkowski's 50-yard field goal for a 3-0 lead.  ''It was the big plays they made,'' Chargers linebacker Shawne Merriman said. ''You have to play a team like that for 60 minutes, and you can't make mistakes because they will capitalize on them.''  San Diego safety Marlon McCree said: ''We were the best team in the N.F.L. with home-field advantage. Our loss is very disappointing.''  Among the supposed soft spots on a Patriots roster that has sustained coaching defections and free-agent losses, the position of kicker stood as a potential weakness this season.  Even though Gostkowski finished his college career at Memphis with 369 points -- placing him 13th in Division I-A history -- replacing a veteran with a rookie seemed risky. Vinatieri had been integral to each of New England's three Super Bowl titles.  Gostkowski said he had never felt bogged down by the task of replacing a Patriots legend.  ''I just kick,'' he said. ''I don't know too much about offense, defense or momentum. I just do my job.''  As Brady led the Patriots down the field in the final minutes, Gostkowski said he figured his number would be called soon.  ''I knew we were in good position,'' he said. ''It was a tie game, and we were ready to win. Game-winning kicks are fun. I haven't had too many experiences with them. I'm glad it worked out.''  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Patriots' Rookie Kicker Ignores Pressure and Fills Large Shoes

content.text: Veteran Softie  Sentimental would probably be the last word anyone would use to describe Bill Belichick, but for the second season in a row he gave one of his veteran players a very public farewell gift.  Last season it was allowing the retiring Doug Flutie to convert an extra point with a drop kick in the season finale. On Sunday against the Titans, he inserted Vinny Testaverde, above, the Patriots' third-string quarterback, with less than three minutes remaining so that he could try to throw a touchdown pass for a 20th consecutive season. Testaverde, who had previously played for Belichick with the Browns and the Jets, found Troy Brown for a 6-yard touchdown with 1 minutes 45 seconds left.  Testaverde, 43, and Brown, 35, have the oldest combined ages for players connecting on an N.F.L. touchdown pass, according to the Elias Sports Bureau.  While Belichick pumped his fists and the Patriots ran to congratulate Testaverde, some of the Titans were fuming. The score increased the Patriots' lead to 40-23. Titans defensive tackle Albert Haynesworth told reporters: ''To bring in a 50-year-old guy to throw a little pass, probably the last pass of his career or of his life, I don't know. Whatever.''  Nice Job, Kid  While Vinny Testaverde was striking a blow for the older generation Sunday, Jets Coach Eric Mangini was joining a different elite subset.  According to the Elias Sports Bureau, since the 1970 A.F.L.-N.F.L. merger, only two coaches younger than Mangini, 35, have led a team to the playoffs: John Madden (twice, at 33 and 34) and Bill Cowher (35).  Mangini and Testaverde may renew acquaintances when the Jets face the Patriots on Sunday. When Testaverde was the starting quarterback for Cleveland in 1984, Mangini, then 13, was breaking into the league as a Browns ball boy.  Thinking Big  Lost amid the record-breaking seasons of LaDainian Tomlinson and Larry Johnson, San Francisco running back Frank Gore broke the 49ers' franchise record with 1,695 rushing yards. He finished third in the N.F.L. and was named to his first Pro Bowl. But he has bigger plans for next season.  ''I'm going for 2,200 next year,'' Gore told reporters as he cleared out his locker Monday. ''That's the record, isn't it? Yeah, I'll get that.''  That would be Eric Dickerson's single-season record of 2,105 yards, set in 15 games in 1984.  Early Checkout  The consolation for Tom Walsh when he was dismissed as the Raiders' offensive coordinator in November was that he could return to the bed-and-breakfast he had run in Idaho. Oakland players like Randy Moss and Jerry Porter remained stuck in their own version of ''Hotel California'' -- they could check out but never leave.  Walsh had been out of the league since 1994, when he was Art Shell's offensive coordinator in Shell's first stint as Raiders coach. When Walsh rejoined Shell this season and installed his old-school offense of long-developing pass plays, the criticism began mounting.  A few days before the season, Moss said, ''Things are so fishy and question mark around here.'' In September, the former Raiders receiver Tim Brown said Walsh's offense was outdated even in the 1990s, calling it horrible and one-dimensional.  In November, quarterback Andrew Walter said the playbook lacked depth. He was promptly benched.  The result was the league's worst offense, which scored 12 touchdowns, or 72 points, in 16 games. By comparison, the Chargers' LaDainian Tomlinson scored 186 points.  A.F.C. Has Its Way  A.F.C. teams had a 40-24 record against N.F.C. teams during the regular season. Three were 4-0, all of them playoff teams -- New England, San Diego and Kansas City. Over all, A.F.C. playoff teams were 21-3 against the N.F.C. in the regular season. More specifically, A.F.C playoff teams were 6-2 against N.F.C playoff teams. N.F.C. playoff teams were 10-14 against A.F.C. teams, with the Giants faring the best at 3-1.  It Wasn't Luck, He Says  Coach Herman Edwards bristled when reporters suggested that the Chiefs were lucky to qualify for the playoffs. ''We didn't luck our way into it,'' Edwards told The Associated Press on Monday. ''We won our way into it, just like those other teams had to win their way into it. And they didn't do it, to be quite honest.''  The Chiefs (9-7) were the beneficiaries of an unlikely series of events. As Edwards famously said when he was Jets coach, ''You play to win the game.''  But it sure helps when everyone else that matters loses theirs.  The Chiefs first had to hand the Jaguars, who were also contending for a playoff spot, their third straight loss, which they did, 35-30.  Next, they needed the Broncos, the Titans and the Bengals to lose at home. The Broncos lost with less than two minutes left in overtime on a 36-yard field goal. The Titans lost after trailing by 3 points going into the fourth quarter. And the Bengals, who also lost in overtime, missed a game-winning field goal at the end of regulation.  Long-Armed Lion  Jon Kitna had 4,208 passing yards this season for the 3-13 Lions, the 30th time in the past 10 seasons that a quarterback has topped 4,000 yards. But Kitna is only the fifth player in that span to do it for a losing team.  The others are Jeff Garcia (4,278 for the 6-10 49ers in 2000), Elvis Grbac (4,164 for the 7-9 Chiefs in 2000), Peyton Manning (4,131 for the 6-10 Colts in 2001) and Trent Green (4,594 for the 7-9 Chiefs in 2004).  The 306-yard performance by Kitna against Dallas on Sunday could have, at least temporarily, saved his job. The win put the Lions behind the Raiders for the top pick in the 2007 draft and may have put Notre Dame quarterback Brady Quinn out of reach.  Extra Points  With the Eagles, the Cowboys and the Giants in the playoffs, this is the first time since realignment in 2002 that three teams from the same division have reached the postseason. The last time that happened was 2001, when three teams from the A.F.C. East (New England, Miami and the Jets) and the N.F.C. Central (Chicago, Tampa Bay and Green Bay) made the playoffs.  Shaun Alexander extended his league record for games with at least one 10-yard run to 64, a span of more than four full seasons.  PRO FOOTBALL  Correction:  January 9, 2007, Tuesday  A report in the Fifth Down football roundup on Thursday about the American Football Conference's dominance over the National Football Conference during the regular season misstated the N.F.C. playoff team that had the best record (3-1) against A.F.C. teams. It is the Dallas Cowboys -- not the Giants, who were 1-3.
content.title: THE FIFTH DOWN

content.text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 18 -- If the New England Patriots beat the Indianapolis Colts and advance to the Super Bowl, it will be a milestone for their 43-year-old backup quarterback, Vinny Testaverde, who has never reached the Super Bowl in 20 N.F.L. seasons.  "Every year I watch it, I think, 'Got away from me again,' " Testaverde said. "Hopefully, this year will be a little different."  The chance to win the Super Bowl, and another chance to play for Bill Belichick, lured Testaverde out of a brief retirement when he signed with the Patriots on Nov. 14 as a backup to Tom Brady. Testaverde's main role is to offer advice and encouragement as a stable presence in a locker room already loaded with experience.  The quarterback duel between Brady and Peyton Manning will be a dominant theme during Sunday's American Football Conference championship game, and Brady has the upper hand, with three Super Bowl titles and two playoff victories over Manning.  Because of those losses, and his failure to reach the Super Bowl, Manning has been targeted for criticism despite a brilliant career. But Testaverde finds it hard to fathom that Manning does not have the makeup to lead a team to a championship,  "I don't know Peyton personally as well as I do Tom, but I think from what I've seen, he has a lot of the same instincts and ability as Tom does," Testaverde said. "He's obviously one of the best. A lot of people don't give him as much credit as he deserves, because he hasn't won the big game yet. It's more than one player when it comes to winning in this sport. A guy as good as he is, sooner or later, he's going to get one, he's going to get a ring."  Though Testaverde barely played this season, a personal high point occurred Dec. 31, when he threw a touchdown pass to Troy Brown during the Patriots' 40-23 victory over Tennessee. The pass was completed with less than two minutes left in the game, and some Titans were not happy. But Belichick wanted Testaverde to become the first N.F.L. player to throw touchdown passes in 20 consecutive seasons, and Testaverde appreciated the opportunity.  "I didn't expect to go in the game at that point, and then when I did, I really didn't think we were going to be throwing the football," Testaverde said. "That situation shows that he does have a sense of history. He lets the team know the accomplishments of certain guys, because guys are proud to be a part of it, too."  Even if the Patriots win the Super Bowl, Testaverde did not guarantee that he would retire -- again.  "This is what I love to do," he said. "I can't think of anything better, and this is a great situation."  FOUR PATRIOTS ARE AILING At least four Patriots had flu symptoms Thursday, three days before New England takes on Indianapolis in the A.F.C. championship game.  Receiver Troy Brown, linebacker Tedy Bruschi, offensive tackle Ryan O'Callaghan and defensive tackle Mike Wright were ailing, but all were expected to be available for Sunday's game.  The hard-hitting safety Rodney Harrison, one of New England's key defensive players, was on the field at the beginning of Thursday's practice, although he missed the previous two playoff games with a knee injury. His status for Sunday was uncertain. Only the beginning of practice was open to the news media, so it was not known how much Harrison participated.
content.title: After 20 Seasons, Testaverde Has a Shot at First Super Bowl

content.text: Tony Romo, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback who went from scrub to celebrity this season, finished where he started.  With 1 minute 19 seconds left in a first-round playoff game against the Seattle Seahawks, Dallas lined up for a potentially game-winning 19-yard field goal. It seemed as automatic as a field goal gets.  But place-kicker Martin Gramatica never had a chance. Romo, the holder on field goals, dropped the snap. He picked up the ball and bolted to his left. He needed only 2 yards to get to the end zone, 1 yard to pick up a first down.  Romo could not get to the end zone and could not get a first down. So the Cowboys lost to the Seahawks, 21-20, at Qwest Field, and have not won a playoff game in 10 years. The second season will now start in Dallas, filled with intriguing questions. Will Coach Bill Parcells retire? Will receiver Terrell Owens be back? Will Romo be the same?  Romo led the Cowboys on a successful two-minute drill in the fourth quarter, keyed by a 35-yard run by tailback Julius Jones. But they could not finish what they started.  The record will show that the game-winning touchdown was caught by Seattle's Jerramy Stevens, whose last playoff game was marred by dropped passes and public humiliation. That playoff game, of course, happened to be last year's Super Bowl.  Stevens grabbed a 37-yard touchdown pass with 4:24 left, capping a frenetic sequence. Seattle had driven to the Dallas 2-yard-line on its previous drive, failed to convert a fourth down, and then scored a safety on what officials initially ruled a touchdown.  The play began when Dallas receiver Terry Glenn caught a pass at the 3-yard-line and was stripped by Seattle cornerback Kelly Jennings. As the ball rolled into the end zone, Seattle's Julian Peterson tried to jump on it. But he only knocked it closer to the sideline.  Lofa Tatupu came next, flipping the ball into the field to prevent it from going out of bounds. Michael Boulware finally recovered the fumble for an apparent touchdown, but it was ruled a safety because Tatupu's left foot was on the sideline.  The play still had its desired effect. After Seattle marched down for a go-ahead touchdown, Hasselbeck pushed place-kicker Josh Brown off the field. The Seahawks wanted a 2-point conversion. When they failed, they left Dallas a window of opportunity.  The player who made the biggest impact for the Cowboys was not Owens, but Miles Austin, an un-drafted rookie from Monmouth. With Dallas trailing by 3 in the third quarter, Austin took a kickoff and tiptoed down the Cowboys' sideline, 93 yards for a touchdown. Several Seahawks swarmed him, but they could not touch him.  Austin, the first player from Monmouth to make a 53-man N.F.L. roster, did not have a return for longer than 37 yards this season. His return Saturday night has to count among Monmouth's football highlights.  The Cowboys' secondary, considered their weak spot, turned for a moment into their strength. One Dallas cornerback, Anthony Henry, intercepted Hasselbeck in the first half. Another cornerback, Terence Newman, created an interception in the second half. Hasselbeck has thrown multiple interceptions in half of his games this season.  Fighting with receiver D. J. Hackett for a jump ball on the sideline, Newman tipped the ball with his right hand. Intentionally or not, he guided it to Roy Williams, a Cowboys' safety. Williams corralled the ball and managed to sneak both feet inbounds.  Even though Seattle went to the Super Bowl last season and Dallas was considered a Super Bowl contender last month, both teams had come to embody the mediocrity of the National Football Conference. The Seahawks and the Cowboys staggered to 9-7 regular-season records, losing three of their last four games.  Seattle and Dallas came into the playoffs with two of the worst pass defenses in the N.F.L. The Seahawks, with three injured cornerbacks, had an excuse for their struggles. The Cowboys, with a full complement of defensive backs, did not.  But the anticipated shootout Saturday did not begin as scheduled. The first touchdown was scored with 11 seconds left in the first half, when Dallas receiver Patrick Crayton caught a pass at the 5-yard-line and stretched into the end zone.  The Cowboys went to halftime with the lead, 10-6, in spite of Owens. On the last drive of the first half, with his team facing a third-and-2 from the Seattle 35-yard-line, Owens dropped his 15th pass of the season.  The Cowboys could have easily sent out Gramatica, who had already made a 50-yard-field goal. But they went for the first down and Romo completed a 32-yard pass to tight end Jason Witten.  Romo's best play of the half might have been an earlier pass to Witten, on a crossing route in the first quarter, but Witten was promptly sandwiched by Seattle linebacker Leroy Hill and Boulware. The ball popped out of Witten's arms and was smothered by cornerback Pete Hunter.  It was amazing that Hunter was even on the field. Two weeks ago, he was working as a loan officer in Dallas, believing his football career was over. But the Seahawks, desperate for defensive backs, looked everywhere for help.  They signed safety John Howell, who was guiding hunts for elk in the Great Plains. They signed cornerback Rich Gardner, who was working out at a gym in Nashville. And they signed Hunter, who has been the most effective of all.  While Hunter was on the field, Marcus Trufant was in the stands. Trufant, perhaps Seattle's best cornerback, stood at the top of Qwest Field before the game and raised the 12th man flag, a local tradition.  Deep into Saturday night, the flag still flew.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: At Crucial Moment, Season Slips Through Cowboys' Fingers

content.text: New England Coach Bill Belichick is apparently worried about getting to the Super Bowl again, not about LaDainian Tomlinson's feelings.  Tomlinson, the Chargers' star running back, was furious at the Patriots for the way they celebrated after their 24-21 playoff victory Sunday in San Diego. Vince Wilfork of the Patriots mocked the sack dance done by San Diego linebacker Shawne Merriman, doing his version on the logo of the Chargers' helmet at midfield. Afterward, Tomlinson said: ''The Patriots showed no class at all. Maybe it comes from the head coach.''  That would be Belichick, who has generally avoided controversy while guiding the Patriots to three Super Bowl victories. During his news conference Wednesday, Belichick would not be drawn into a battle of words with Tomlinson, especially with his team one victory from winning another American Football Conference championship.  ''I have all the respect in the world for LaDainian Tomlinson and the San Diego Chargers,'' Belichick said. ''They are an outstanding football team. But right now, our focus is on the Indianapolis Colts.''  Belichick and Tomlinson could be reunited at next month's Pro Bowl. If the Patriots lose Sunday, Belichick will coach the A.F.C. team that Tomlinson will play for. Tomlinson, however, did not sound ready to forgive and forget.  ''I don't know how that would go over,'' he said Monday when asked about the Pro Bowl. ''I probably wouldn't say two words to him.''  Belichick is not planning to be at the Pro Bowl. He is planning on winning another Super Bowl, as is Patriots quarterback Tom Brady.  ''I think we always try to represent ourselves a certain way,'' Brady said of the San Diego postgame incident. ''That's up to Coach Belichick to talk about that with the players. I think we've tried to move on from that. We've won a bunch of meaningful games in the past. Some of it is just raw emotion. Some of it, maybe, does go a little bit too far. I think what happened, happened, and we're moving on.''  PRO FOOTBALL: PLAYOFF ROUNDUP
content.title: As Tomlinson Looks Back in Anger, the Patriots Look Forward to the Colts

content.text: The locker room was quiet, players spoke in hushed tones, and the New England Patriots felt as empty as many of their past victims.  This was an unfamiliar finish for the Patriots, losing an 18-point second-quarter lead and the American Football Conference championship game. Sunday's 38-34 victory by the Indianapolis Colts will be remembered as a classic playoff game, but for the Patriots, the second half was a nightmare.  They were shredded by Peyton Manning and the Indianapolis offense. They dropped passes. They committed key penalties. And in the end, quarterback Tom Brady ran out of magic and time.  Having won three Super Bowls in the past five seasons, the Patriots saw the opportunity to win another snatched away. There will be plenty of time for self-analysis. But immediately afterward, the prevailing feeling among the Patriots was disappointment.  ''It'll take a good while to swallow this one,'' said linebacker Tedy Bruschi, a member of the Patriots' three Super Bowl winners. ''I put so much into this season. I'm really emotional right now. This game was momentum swings on top of momentum swings. And theirs was the one that finished it.''  The Colts dissected New England's proud defense in the second half, scoring on five of seven second-half possessions, not counting the knee that Manning took to end the game. The Patriots could not stop the Colts when it counted most. They were protecting a 34-31 lead with 2 minutes 17 seconds to play, when Indianapolis regained possession on its 20.  From that point, Manning engineered a drive that will take its place in N.F.L. lore, moving the Colts 80 yards in seven plays for the winning touchdown, a 3-yard run by Joseph Addai.  Uncharacteristically, the Patriots surrendered yardage in chunks during that decisive drive. Manning completed a 32-yard pass to Bryan Fletcher and another for 14 yards to Reggie Wayne.  On that play, Patriots defensive end Tully Banta-Cain was penalized for roughing the passer, moving the ball from New England's 23-yard line to the 11 with 1:53 left.  Without that penalty, perhaps the Colts would have settled for a tying field goal that would probably have forced overtime. Instead, the Colts called Addai's number on three consecutive running plays, the final one resulting in a touchdown.  That left the Patriots trailing by 4 points with 54 seconds and two timeouts remaining. when they took over at their 21.  Even for Brady, this was a nearly impossible situation. Four plays later, he tried to force a pass to Ben Watson that was intercepted by Marlin Jackson with 16 seconds to play. Indianapolis could celebrate. The Patriots could reflect.  ''We just let too many opportunities slip away,'' said Brady, who completed 21 of 34 passes, for 232 yards and a touchdown. ''The last pass, you're just trying to force it, make a play. In hindsight, you probably should throw it away. But time was an issue.  ''It's frustrating for all of us when it ends like this, because the expectations are high. We just have to come back next year and try to do it better.''  The Patriots appeared to have the Colts on the run in the second quarter, after New England defensive back Asante Samuel cut in front of a pass intended for Marvin Harrison and returned the ball 39 yards for a touchdown. The extra point gave the Patriots a 21-3 lead, and they stopped Indianapolis on its next drive.  But after reaching the Colts' 27, the Patriots committed back-to-back penalties and eventually punted.  That gave the Colts a chance to regroup, and they managed a 12-play drive for a field goal that pulled them to 21-6 at halftime.  In the second half, the Colts' offensive machine clicked, and the Patriots at times looked tired and a step slow.  ''They're a high-powered offense,'' Patriots linebacker Mike Vrabel said. ''We knew the game wasn't over.''  Asked if he was disappointed that the Patriots could not generate more of a pass rush against Manning, defensive end Ty Warren said: ''You not only have to get to him, you have to get to him quick. They run timing patterns. If you don't get there, the ball is gone.''  The Patriots had a chance to run out the clock, getting the ball with 3:32 left and leading by 34-31. But they were stopped after three plays, giving Manning the opportunity to orchestrate his final drive.  So instead of going to another Super Bowl, Brady will be watching it. Or will he?  ''Knowing me, probably not,'' Brady said. ''Probably not.''  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: In Role Reversal, New England Fades With Game on the Line

content.text: Brian Schottenheimer, who just completed his first season as the Jets' offensive coordinator, removed his name from consideration for the Miami Dolphins' coaching job yesterday.  Schottenheimer, 33, met for a preliminary interview with the Dolphins' owner, Wayne Huizenga, in the New York area last week. He was one of three candidates invited back for a second interview. The former Falcons coach Jim Mora and Georgia Tech Coach Chan Gailey were the others.  In a statement announcing his decision, Schottenheimer, who was the quarterbacks coach for the San Diego Chargers before moving to New York, said, ''I am committed to the New York Jets.''  Schottenheimer's liberal use of shifts, motions and formations gave the Jets' offense a kaleidoscope of looks that made defending it a challenge. In a statement, Coach Eric Mangini acknowledged Schottenheimer's contribution to the success of the Jets, who were defeated in the first round of the playoffs by the New England Patriots after finishing the regular season 10-6.  ''Brian's creative approach on offense was an integral part of our progress in the 2006 season,'' Mangini said in a statement, ''and I'm pleased he will remain with the Jets to build on that progress.''  DECLARING FOR DRAFT -- Ted Ginn Jr., Ohio State's game-breaking receiver and return man, and Adrian Peterson, Oklahoma's fleet running back, will pass up their senior seasons to enter the N.F.L. draft. Yesterday was the deadline for underclassmen to declare their intentions.  A week after his team lost to Florida, 41-14, in the Bowl Championship Series title game, Ohio State tailback Antonio Pittman also said he was leaving early for the N.F.L.  Colt Brennan, the record-breaking Hawaii quarterback, declared himself eligible for the draft, too, but left himself the option of returning to the Warriors. Louisville quarterback Brian Brohm, however, said he was staying in college.  Ginn and Pittman will join Ohio State receiver Anthony Gonzalez, who announced last week that he would give up his final season of eligibility to turn pro.  Peterson will also pass up his senior year. He missed seven games last season because of a broken collarbone, and still ran for 1,012 yards and 12 touchdowns.  Brennan set the N.C.A.A. record with 58 touchdown passes last season in leading Hawaii to an 11-3 record. (AP)  STEELERS NARROW SEARCH TO THREE -- The assistant head coach Russ Grimm has emerged as the front-runner for the Steelers' coaching job, a search that was narrowed to three finalists yesterday after the offensive coordinator Ken Whisenhunt left for Arizona.  The Steelers identified Grimm, a Pittsburgh assistant for six years, and the defensive coordinators Mike Tomlin of the Vikings and Ron Rivera of the Bears as the finalists to replace Bill Cowher. (AP)  COORDINATORS ON THE MOVE -- The Ravens promoted Rick Neuheisel to offensive coordinator, although Coach Brian Billick said he would continue to call the plays next season.  The Panthers fired Dan Henning, their offensive coordinator.  The Packers promoted Joe Philbin, the team's offensive line coach, to replace Jeff Jagodzinski as the team's offensive coordinator. Jagodzinski was hired as head coach at Boston College last month. (AP)  AROUND THE LEAGUE -- Robbie Tobeck, the Seahawks' former Pro Bowl center, retired yesterday.  Seahawks quarterback Matt Hasselbeck said that he played the final eight games of Seattle's season with broken fingers on his nonpassing hand. (AP)  N.F.L. ROUNDUP
content.title: Jet Assistant Won't Seek Dolphins' Vacancy

content.text: Kicking and scheming, 8 of the N.F.L.'s 12 playoff teams will be in action this weekend in back-to-back doubleheaders.  KANSAS CITY AT INDIANAPOLIS  4:30 p.m., NBC  DALLAS AT SEATTLE  8 p.m., NBC  TODAY -- The games include a team that was in last year's Super Bowl (the Seahawks), a team that can't seem to get to the Super Bowl (the Colts) and a coach (the Cowboys' Bill Parcells) who would like to get there one more time.  JETS AT NEW ENGLAND  1 p.m., CBS  GIANTS  AT PHILADELPHIA  4:30 p.m., Fox  TOMORROW -- The pairings feature division rivals, with the Jets trying to upset the Patriots for the second time this season and the slumping, but fortunate, Giants trying to justify their presence by surprising the Eagles.  PRO FOOTBALL

Tom Brady has an impeccable reputation for postseason heroics. But when the Colts beat the Patriots in November, Brady threw four interceptions. And when the Patriots beat the Chargers last week, Brady was picked off three times.  The conclusion?  ''He will throw you some,'' Colts cornerback Nick Harper said. ''No quarterback is perfect. If you have great coverage, sometimes he tends to throw the ball into coverage. I guess he feels like all his receivers are better than the defensive backs. He will throw the ball into coverage. We watched the New England game. He threw a lot of balls to the opposing team, but they didn't catch them.''  Brady and the Patriots, who will face the Colts at the RCA Dome in the A.F.C. championship game Sunday, have beaten the Colts twice recently in the playoffs: in the A.F.C. title game in Foxborough after the 2003 season, and in a second-round game the next year. But the Colts have won regular-season games the past two years.  Brady's play in the November loss was particularly uncharacteristic. It was a low point in a season in which Brady and his revamped corps of receivers struggled to find a chemistry, something that has come together only in recent weeks. Brady threw for 24 touchdowns and 12 interceptions in the regular season; he never threw more than two interceptions in any other game.  Still, Harper's harsh assessment is likely to find its way to a New England bulletin board this week. His comments stood out on a day when the Colts hewed to the company line that past performance meant nothing in the rivalry.  Brady's postseason record is beyond reproach; he is 12-1 in playoff games, losing only to the Broncos last season. But Harper said he thought Brady's recent struggles against the Indianapolis might be a sign that Colts were planted firmly in his head.  ''I would think so,'' Harper said. ''He knows if he makes a mistake, we're good enough to take advantage of it.''  JUDY BATTISTA  PRO FOOTBALL: PLAYOFF ROUNDUP
content.title: Colts Confident Against Pats

content.text: In a wild Fiesta Bowl that featured 18 unanswered fourth-quarter points by Oklahoma, and a hook-and-lateral play with seven seconds remaining to force overtime by Boise State, it was only fitting that the Broncos won with another bit of trickery, a Statue of Liberty play.  Boise State won in overtime, 43-42, when the Broncos scored on a touchdown pass thrown by a wide receiver and went for a 2-point conversion. Quarterback Jared Zabransky handed the ball behind his back to tailback Ian Johnson, who ran in untouched, completing one of the wildest and most important upsets in college football history.  Boise State squandered an 18-point second-half lead and appeared destined to lose when Zabransky threw an interception to Oklahoma cornerback Marcus Walker that was returned 33 yards for a touchdown with 1 minute 2 seconds remaining in the game.  That gave Oklahoma a 35-28 lead, which appeared destined to stand until Boise State reached into its bag of tricks on a last-ditch play at the end of regulation.  Zabransky hit Drisan James over the middle for a 15-yard gain, and James flipped the ball to Jerard Rabb, who then ran the ball 40 yards for a touchdown with seven seconds remaining in regulation.  The play will go down in college football lore as the linchpin play in an epic game.  The trickery did not end for Boise State in overtime. Facing a fourth-and-2, the Broncos lined up wide receiver Vinny Perretta at quarterback, and he completed a pass to tight end Derek Schouman for a 5-yard touchdown. A conversion kick could have tied the score, but Boise State Coach Chris Petersen decided to go for 2. After Oklahoma called a timeout, the Broncos executed a textbook Statue of Liberty play to seal the improbable victory.  The win will shake the core of the college football establishment, as Oklahoma of the Big 12 entered the game heavily favored. The Broncos, who famously play their games on a blue turf field, won the biggest game in their program's history by defeating one of college football's blue bloods.  In doing so, Boise State showed that the best team from outside college football's six power conferences could play with the champion from a conference like the Big 12.  In the first year of the B.C.S.'s double-hosting format, which was founded in part to allow access to teams outside the power conferences a better chance at reaching the top-tier bowl games, the Broncos more than justified the decision.  Thanks to four critical turnovers by Oklahoma quarterback Paul Thompson, Oklahoma was playing from behind all night. Boise was more timely than dominant, as it used a series of big plays and exploited turnovers to compensate for its size and athleticism disadvantages.  The Broncos were able to slow down the star tailback Adrian Peterson, who returned from a seven game absence with a broken collarbone and rushed for 77 yards on 20 carries in what's expected to be his final collegiate game. Peterson's biggest run of the night came in the first overtime when he ran the ball in from 25 yards out on the first play.  But even Peterson's star power didn't matter.  It's only fitting that N.C.A.A. basketball upstart George Mason took out a full-page ad in The Idaho Statesman this week, one David sending good luck wishes from two time zones away. Much like Mason's stunning run to the Final Four last March was viewed as a victory for the little guy in college basketball, Boise's victory could be seen the same way for football.  It will be long lost in history that the Broncos actually entered the game ranked No. 8, two spots higher than an Oklahoma team that battled attrition, injuries and questionable officiating in a trying season.  All that will be remembered is that a team from Boise that's been a Division I-A football member for 11 years topped a program that's won seven national championships and produced 142 all-Americans.  Boise pulled out the victory after Oklahoma launched a stunning comeback. The Sooners tied the game at 28 1:26 remaining after Thompson completed a 2-point conversion on O.U.'s third attempt, as penalties marred the other two.  That was just one wild sequence in a frenetic finish that will long live in the lore of underdogs and trickery in college football.  COLLEGE FOOTBALL
content.title: Playbook Full of Tricks Helps Boise State Prove Its Worth
